Hong Kong protests are growing smaller but more violent and ugly

By James Griffiths, CNN
Updated at 0416 GMT (1216 HKT) September 16, 2019



Hong Kong protests continue for 15th straight week 01:40

Hong Kong (CNN) — Dozens of people were injured Sunday in another night of violence in Hong Kong, as the city marked its fifteenth consecutive weekend of anti-government protests.

Thousands of people took part in a peaceful -- albeit unauthorized -- march from Causeway Bay to government offices in Admiralty, calling for the government to respond to the protest movement's five demands. That quickly turned violent after radical protesters gathered outside the legislature and began throwing bricks and petrol bombs at police lines.

Police responded with tear gas and water cannon, using jets of blue dye for the second time. The dye -- which is also laced with tear gas -- is designed to indelibly mark protesters and make them easy to arrest later.

The heavy response drove protesters back from the legislature and began a night of cat-and-mouse pursuit throughout the city, which saw protesters set fires and vandalize subway stations as police made sporadic arrests.

At least 28 people were injured Sunday, according to the hospital authority. Of those, 13 men and four women have been discharged as of Monday morning, while 11 remain in hospital. Two men are in a "serious condition," the authority said.



While the violence between police and protesters was fairly regular compared to previous weeks, the ugliest scenes occurred at the edges of the protests, where both protester and pro-government groups attacked people who disagreed with them.

CNN reporters saw a mob of masked protesters attacking a man in the Tin Hau neighborhood after a brief confrontation, leaving him dazed and bleeding on the floor. In an earlier incident, video shared widely online showed a middle-aged man wearing a blue shirt attacked and left apparently unconscious by a large group of mostly young, black-clad protesters on Gloucester Road. According to the South China Morning Post, the unidentified man had shouted pro-police slogans before the attack

Later on Sunday, a group of mostly middle-aged men were seen striking and threatening protesters in the North Point area. The area has a large mainland Chinese immigrant population, and there have been attacks on protesters in the area in past weeks.

Sunday's violence came after a number of angry scuffles on Saturday between pro and anti-government groups, though none reached the level of violence seen the following day. Pro-Beijing groups sang the Chinese national anthem and pulled down "Lennon Walls," collections of notes and flyers erected by protesters, around the city.

On Friday, pro-government lawmaker Junius Ho called on patriotic Hong Kongers to "get together and clean Hong Kong." Ho previously praised alleged triads who attacked protesters in Yuen Long, and appeared to threaten to kill one of his colleagues after they argued on a radio show.

寫左段英文回應私了，希望有用。歡迎改動、各式轉載。

Dear friends,

Today we've seen Hong Kong protesters resorting to violence when a man attacked the protesters. Said man was critically injured. This would be unacceptable in many people's eyes. I am not trying to say that it should be encouraged but would like to provide a wider picture for the incidence and why we should still support the movement even with violence escalates.

Violence should be seen as the result of the collapse of the rule of law, which is wholly due to the failure of the police force and the judicial system. In the past 2 months, we have witnessed thugs and mobsters attacking protesters and civilians alike with no consequences. It is commonplace now that anyone who use violence against protesters can walk freely away, sometimes even escorted by the police. On the contrary, people beaten by pro-government camps were seen arrested. Many protesters being assaulted are afraid of reporting to the police because they might be prosecuted in turn. Many have avoided going to the hospital even injured because it is known that the police are arresting peaceful protesters when they seek treatment. Protest medics and underground doctors have stated that they were on the brink of collapse in handling cases.

Protesters have all the reasons to lose any kind of confidence in the police. And it is clear that the police is not protecting the people from any pro-government violence. There is no one coming to their rescue when help is needed. The people did not willfully take things into their own hands, but were forced by the circumstances. People resort to violence when facing assault because that is the only way they can protect themselves and their loved ones.

On the other hand, protesters also have a strong sense of justice. Time and again, they have seen thugs and mobsters let go by the police. The judicial system has lost people's trust when the lawbreakers are constantly released. This would be the very reason that excessive violence happens when the protesters get a chance to punish the thugs. It's not for the current act of the particular thug they face that they try to redress. It's for all the crimes of the lawbreakers that walk away under the police's watch.

I certainly agree that this kind of crude justice cannot replace the rule of law that we adhere to. But it is exactly why we should stand with the movement. The Hong Kong people has always been known as some of the most law-abiding citizens in the world. What turns us into violent protesters is the absence of the rule of law, the failure of the police and the judicial system.

The very answer to the current situation has already been written as the five demands, especially the last one. We want democracy now because that is our basic rights, which is promised in the joint declaration and our mini constitution, and that is the only way we can have a government accountable to the people. In so doing, we can start to rebuild our police force and judicial system. Only then, the Hong Kong people can be protected, and be sure that justice is upheld.

The Hong Kong and Chinese government might respond to the violence of people by an iron fist. Order might come by because of strong suppression. However, that would effectively make Hong Kong a police state. Without democracy and a government accountable to the people, oppression will persist. Police brutality will have no resolution. We already see how some corporations are required to fire employees that show their support for the movement on social media. We have good reasons to believe that this will become commonplace if the movement dies down.

It is a dire time for the Hong Kong people. Violence is escalating. Social order is crumbling down. But we are in the fight to rescue it and build it upon a real democracy. Please stand with us, stand with freedom.

Yours,
A Hongkonger

quote.msg:
Hong Kong protests are growing smaller but more violent and ugly

By James Griffiths, CNN
Updated at 0416 GMT (1216 HKT) September 16, 2019



Hong Kong protests continue for 15th straight week 01:40

Hong Kong (CNN) — Dozens of people were injured Sunday in another night of violence in Hong Kong, as the city marked its fifteenth consecutive weekend of anti-government protests.

Thousands of people took part in a peaceful -- albeit unauthorized -- march from Causeway Bay to government offices in Admiralty, calling for the government to respond to the protest movement's five demands. That quickly turned violent after radical protesters gathered outside the legislature and began throwing bricks and petrol bombs at police lines.

Police responded with tear gas and water cannon, using jets of blue dye for the second time. The dye -- which is also laced with tear gas -- is designed to indelibly mark protesters and make them easy to arrest later.

The heavy response drove protesters back from the legislature and began a night of cat-and-mouse pursuit throughout the city, which saw protesters set fires and vandalize subway stations as police made sporadic arrests.

At least 28 people were injured Sunday, according to the hospital authority. Of those, 13 men and four women have been discharged as of Monday morning, while 11 remain in hospital. Two men are in a "serious condition," the authority said.



While the violence between police and protesters was fairly regular compared to previous weeks, the ugliest scenes occurred at the edges of the protests, where both protester and pro-government groups attacked people who disagreed with them.

CNN reporters saw a mob of masked protesters attacking a man in the Tin Hau neighborhood after a brief confrontation, leaving him dazed and bleeding on the floor. In an earlier incident, video shared widely online showed a middle-aged man wearing a blue shirt attacked and left apparently unconscious by a large group of mostly young, black-clad protesters on Gloucester Road. According to the South China Morning Post, the unidentified man had shouted pro-police slogans before the attack

Later on Sunday, a group of mostly middle-aged men were seen striking and threatening protesters in the North Point area. The area has a large mainland Chinese immigrant population, and there have been attacks on protesters in the area in past weeks.

Sunday's violence came after a number of angry scuffles on Saturday between pro and anti-government groups, though none reached the level of violence seen the following day. Pro-Beijing groups sang the Chinese national anthem and pulled down "Lennon Walls," collections of notes and flyers erected by protesters, around the city.

On Friday, pro-government lawmaker Junius Ho called on patriotic Hong Kongers to "get together and clean Hong Kong." Ho previously praised alleged triads who attacked protesters in Yuen Long, and appeared to threaten to kill one of his colleagues after they argued on a radio show.

寫左段英文回應私了，希望有用。歡迎改動、各式轉載。

Dear friends,

Today we've seen Hong Kong protesters resorting to violence when a man attacked the protesters. Said man was critically injured. This would be unacceptable in many people's eyes. I am not trying to say that it should be encouraged but would like to provide a wider picture for the incidence and why we should still support the movement even with violence escalates.

Violence should be seen as the result of the collapse of the rule of law, which is wholly due to the failure of the police force and the judicial system. In the past 2 months, we have witnessed thugs and mobsters attacking protesters and civilians alike with no consequences. It is commonplace now that anyone who use violence against protesters can walk freely away, sometimes even escorted by the police. On the contrary, people beaten by pro-government camps were seen arrested. Many protesters being assaulted are afraid of reporting to the police because they might be prosecuted in turn. Many have avoided going to the hospital even injured because it is known that the police are arresting peaceful protesters when they seek treatment. Protest medics and underground doctors have stated that they were on the brink of collapse in handling cases.

Protesters have all the reasons to lose any kind of confidence in the police. And it is clear that the police is not protecting the people from any pro-government violence. There is no one coming to their rescue when help is needed. The people did not willfully take things into their own hands, but were forced by the circumstances. People resort to violence when facing assault because that is the only way they can protect themselves and their loved ones.

On the other hand, protesters also have a strong sense of justice. Time and again, they have seen thugs and mobsters let go by the police. The judicial system has lost people's trust when the lawbreakers are constantly released. This would be the very reason that excessive violence happens when the protesters get a chance to punish the thugs. It's not for the current act of the particular thug they face that they try to redress. It's for all the crimes of the lawbreakers that walk away under the police's watch.

I certainly agree that this kind of crude justice cannot replace the rule of law that we adhere to. But it is exactly why we should stand with the movement. The Hong Kong people has always been known as some of the most law-abiding citizens in the world. What turns us into violent protesters is the absence of the rule of law, the failure of the police and the judicial system.

The very answer to the current situation has already been written as the five demands, especially the last one. We want democracy now because that is our basic rights, which is promised in the joint declaration and our mini constitution, and that is the only way we can have a government accountable to the people. In so doing, we can start to rebuild our police force and judicial system. Only then, the Hong Kong people can be protected, and be sure that justice is upheld.

The Hong Kong and Chinese government might respond to the violence of people by an iron fist. Order might come by because of strong suppression. However, that would effectively make Hong Kong a police state. Without democracy and a government accountable to the people, oppression will persist. Police brutality will have no resolution. We already see how some corporations are required to fire employees that show their support for the movement on social media. We have good reasons to believe that this will become commonplace if the movement dies down.

It is a dire time for the Hong Kong people. Violence is escalating. Social order is crumbling down. But we are in the fight to rescue it and build it upon a real democracy. Please stand with us, stand with freedom.

Yours,
A Hongkonger

quote.msg:
Hong Kong protests are growing smaller but more violent and ugly

By James Griffiths, CNN
Updated at 0416 GMT (1216 HKT) September 16, 2019



Hong Kong protests continue for 15th straight week 01:40

Hong Kong (CNN) — Dozens of people were injured Sunday in another night of violence in Hong Kong, as the city marked its fifteenth consecutive weekend of anti-government protests.

Thousands of people took part in a peaceful -- albeit unauthorized -- march from Causeway Bay to government offices in Admiralty, calling for the government to respond to the protest movement's five demands. That quickly turned violent after radical protesters gathered outside the legislature and began throwing bricks and petrol bombs at police lines.

Police responded with tear gas and water cannon, using jets of blue dye for the second time. The dye -- which is also laced with tear gas -- is designed to indelibly mark protesters and make them easy to arrest later.

The heavy response drove protesters back from the legislature and began a night of cat-and-mouse pursuit throughout the city, which saw protesters set fires and vandalize subway stations as police made sporadic arrests.

At least 28 people were injured Sunday, according to the hospital authority. Of those, 13 men and four women have been discharged as of Monday morning, while 11 remain in hospital. Two men are in a "serious condition," the authority said.



While the violence between police and protesters was fairly regular compared to previous weeks, the ugliest scenes occurred at the edges of the protests, where both protester and pro-government groups attacked people who disagreed with them.

CNN reporters saw a mob of masked protesters attacking a man in the Tin Hau neighborhood after a brief confrontation, leaving him dazed and bleeding on the floor. In an earlier incident, video shared widely online showed a middle-aged man wearing a blue shirt attacked and left apparently unconscious by a large group of mostly young, black-clad protesters on Gloucester Road. According to the South China Morning Post, the unidentified man had shouted pro-police slogans before the attack

Later on Sunday, a group of mostly middle-aged men were seen striking and threatening protesters in the North Point area. The area has a large mainland Chinese immigrant population, and there have been attacks on protesters in the area in past weeks.

Sunday's violence came after a number of angry scuffles on Saturday between pro and anti-government groups, though none reached the level of violence seen the following day. Pro-Beijing groups sang the Chinese national anthem and pulled down "Lennon Walls," collections of notes and flyers erected by protesters, around the city.

On Friday, pro-government lawmaker Junius Ho called on patriotic Hong Kongers to "get together and clean Hong Kong." Ho previously praised alleged triads who attacked protesters in Yuen Long, and appeared to threaten to kill one of his colleagues after they argued on a radio show.

by達寧李

寫左段英文回應私了，希望有用。歡迎改動、各式轉載。

Dear friends,

Today we've seen Hong Kong protesters resorting to violence when a man attacked the protesters. Said man was critically injured. This would be unacceptable in many people's eyes. I am not trying to say that it should be encouraged but would like to provide a wider picture for the incidence and why we should still support the movement even with violence escalates.

Violence should be seen as the result of the collapse of the rule of law, which is wholly due to the failure of the police force and the judicial system. In the past 2 months, we have witnessed thugs and mobsters attacking protesters and civilians alike with no consequences. It is commonplace now that anyone who use violence against protesters can walk freely away, sometimes even escorted by the police. On the contrary, people beaten by pro-government camps were seen arrested. Many protesters being assaulted are afraid of reporting to the police because they might be prosecuted in turn. Many have avoided going to the hospital even injured because it is known that the police are arresting peaceful protesters when they seek treatment. Protest medics and underground doctors have stated that they were on the brink of collapse in handling cases.

Protesters have all the reasons to lose any kind of confidence in the police. And it is clear that the police is not protecting the people from any pro-government violence. There is no one coming to their rescue when help is needed. The people did not willfully take things into their own hands, but were forced by the circumstances. People resort to violence when facing assault because that is the only way they can protect themselves and their loved ones.

On the other hand, protesters also have a strong sense of justice. Time and again, they have seen thugs and mobsters let go by the police. The judicial system has lost people's trust when the lawbreakers are constantly released. This would be the very reason that excessive violence happens when the protesters get a chance to punish the thugs. It's not for the current act of the particular thug they face that they try to redress. It's for all the crimes of the lawbreakers that walk away under the police's watch.

I certainly agree that this kind of crude justice cannot replace the rule of law that we adhere to. But it is exactly why we should stand with the movement. The Hong Kong people has always been known as some of the most law-abiding citizens in the world. What turns us into violent protesters is the absence of the rule of law, the failure of the police and the judicial system.

The very answer to the current situation has already been written as the five demands, especially the last one. We want democracy now because that is our basic rights, which is promised in the joint declaration and our mini constitution, and that is the only way we can have a government accountable to the people. In so doing, we can start to rebuild our police force and judicial system. Only then, the Hong Kong people can be protected, and be sure that justice is upheld.

The Hong Kong and Chinese government might respond to the violence of people by an iron fist. Order might come by because of strong suppression. However, that would effectively make Hong Kong a police state. Without democracy and a government accountable to the people, oppression will persist. Police brutality will have no resolution. We already see how some corporations are required to fire employees that show their support for the movement on social media. We have good reasons to believe that this will become commonplace if the movement dies down.

It is a dire time for the Hong Kong people. Violence is escalating. Social order is crumbling down. But we are in the fight to rescue it and build it upon a real democracy. Please stand with us, stand with freedom.

Yours,
A Hongkonger

quote.msg:
Hong Kong protests are growing smaller but more violent and ugly

By James Griffiths, CNN
Updated at 0416 GMT (1216 HKT) September 16, 2019



Hong Kong protests continue for 15th straight week 01:40

Hong Kong (CNN) — Dozens of people were injured Sunday in another night of violence in Hong Kong, as the city marked its fifteenth consecutive weekend of anti-government protests.

Thousands of people took part in a peaceful -- albeit unauthorized -- march from Causeway Bay to government offices in Admiralty, calling for the government to respond to the protest movement's five demands. That quickly turned violent after radical protesters gathered outside the legislature and began throwing bricks and petrol bombs at police lines.

Police responded with tear gas and water cannon, using jets of blue dye for the second time. The dye -- which is also laced with tear gas -- is designed to indelibly mark protesters and make them easy to arrest later.

The heavy response drove protesters back from the legislature and began a night of cat-and-mouse pursuit throughout the city, which saw protesters set fires and vandalize subway stations as police made sporadic arrests.

At least 28 people were injured Sunday, according to the hospital authority. Of those, 13 men and four women have been discharged as of Monday morning, while 11 remain in hospital. Two men are in a "serious condition," the authority said.



While the violence between police and protesters was fairly regular compared to previous weeks, the ugliest scenes occurred at the edges of the protests, where both protester and pro-government groups attacked people who disagreed with them.

CNN reporters saw a mob of masked protesters attacking a man in the Tin Hau neighborhood after a brief confrontation, leaving him dazed and bleeding on the floor. In an earlier incident, video shared widely online showed a middle-aged man wearing a blue shirt attacked and left apparently unconscious by a large group of mostly young, black-clad protesters on Gloucester Road. According to the South China Morning Post, the unidentified man had shouted pro-police slogans before the attack

Later on Sunday, a group of mostly middle-aged men were seen striking and threatening protesters in the North Point area. The area has a large mainland Chinese immigrant population, and there have been attacks on protesters in the area in past weeks.

Sunday's violence came after a number of angry scuffles on Saturday between pro and anti-government groups, though none reached the level of violence seen the following day. Pro-Beijing groups sang the Chinese national anthem and pulled down "Lennon Walls," collections of notes and flyers erected by protesters, around the city.

On Friday, pro-government lawmaker Junius Ho called on patriotic Hong Kongers to "get together and clean Hong Kong." Ho previously praised alleged triads who attacked protesters in Yuen Long, and appeared to threaten to kill one of his colleagues after they argued on a radio show.

Hong Kong protests are growing smaller but more violent and ugly

By James Griffiths, CNN
Updated at 0416 GMT (1216 HKT) September 16, 2019



Hong Kong protests continue for 15th straight week 01:40

Hong Kong (CNN) — Dozens of people were injured Sunday in another night of violence in Hong Kong, as the city marked its fifteenth consecutive weekend of anti-government protests.

Thousands of people took part in a peaceful -- albeit unauthorized -- march from Causeway Bay to government offices in Admiralty, calling for the government to respond to the protest movement's five demands. That quickly turned violent after radical protesters gathered outside the legislature and began throwing bricks and petrol bombs at police lines.

Police responded with tear gas and water cannon, using jets of blue dye for the second time. The dye -- which is also laced with tear gas -- is designed to indelibly mark protesters and make them easy to arrest later.

The heavy response drove protesters back from the legislature and began a night of cat-and-mouse pursuit throughout the city, which saw protesters set fires and vandalize subway stations as police made sporadic arrests.

At least 28 people were injured Sunday, according to the hospital authority. Of those, 13 men and four women have been discharged as of Monday morning, while 11 remain in hospital. Two men are in a "serious condition," the authority said.



While the violence between police and protesters was fairly regular compared to previous weeks, the ugliest scenes occurred at the edges of the protests, where both protester and pro-government groups attacked people who disagreed with them.

CNN reporters saw a mob of masked protesters attacking a man in the Tin Hau neighborhood after a brief confrontation, leaving him dazed and bleeding on the floor. In an earlier incident, video shared widely online showed a middle-aged man wearing a blue shirt attacked and left apparently unconscious by a large group of mostly young, black-clad protesters on Gloucester Road. According to the South China Morning Post, the unidentified man had shouted pro-police slogans before the attack

Later on Sunday, a group of mostly middle-aged men were seen striking and threatening protesters in the North Point area. The area has a large mainland Chinese immigrant population, and there have been attacks on protesters in the area in past weeks.

Sunday's violence came after a number of angry scuffles on Saturday between pro and anti-government groups, though none reached the level of violence seen the following day. Pro-Beijing groups sang the Chinese national anthem and pulled down "Lennon Walls," collections of notes and flyers erected by protesters, around the city.

On Friday, pro-government lawmaker Junius Ho called on patriotic Hong Kongers to "get together and clean Hong Kong." Ho previously praised alleged triads who attacked protesters in Yuen Long, and appeared to threaten to kill one of his colleagues after they argued on a radio show.

The fury and aggression of protesters tonight must be viewed in the context of everything that has happened before.

1. The Chinese Communist Party hired numerous violent thugs to attack Hong Kong citizens. The reactions over the past three months have been very restrained with citizens seeking to avoid conflict by separating out the attackers. However the effects were less than ideal with ever-increasing aggression on the part of the attackers, for example the indiscriminate attack in Yuen Long on 21 July; stabbing and puncturing a young woman’s lung by a Lennon wall; kniving and permanently crippling a protester at Tsuen Wan, .. etc.

2. Collusion between the police, the government, and gangs: Citizens have upheld peace and trusted the rule of law over the past few months, and have chosen to call the police when attacked. But in contract the police have turned a blind eye after arriving on the scene. After the attackers were done brutalizing our citizens, the police had unbelievably escorted their exits while arresting the victims, sometimes even making charges against them. This could be seen in multiple districts on 14 September.

3. Planned Attacks: Most perpetrators are equipped with lethal weapons such as knives and metal bars when attacking non-confrontational citizens. It is only with nothing to fend for themselves, and combined with the above history that protesters are so furious and aggressive, leading to what we saw today.

Should such scenes cause distress among members of the public or our supporters overseas, we, Hongkongers, hereby offer our most sincere apologies. We really don’t know how to protect ourselves. After seeing how our old and weak, women and children are treated with violence again and again over the past three months, we finally had to resort to something that we wanted the least. Let it be stressed again that when not being attacked, protesters and citizens will not use any force as a means of self-defence. Please forgive us. May peace, freedom, love and rule of law but return to Hong Kong.

Yours,
An ordinary HongKonger

寫左段英文回應私了，希望有用。歡迎改動、各式轉載。

Dear friends,

Today we've seen Hong Kong protesters resorting to violence when a man attacked the protesters. Said man was critically injured. This would be unacceptable in many people's eyes. I am not trying to say that it should be encouraged but would like to provide a wider picture for the incidence and why we should still support the movement even with violence escalates.

Violence should be seen as the result of the collapse of the rule of law, which is wholly due to the failure of the police force and the judicial system. In the past 2 months, we have witnessed thugs and mobsters attacking protesters and civilians alike with no consequences. It is commonplace now that anyone who use violence against protesters can walk freely away, sometimes even escorted by the police. On the contrary, people beaten by pro-government camps were seen arrested. Many protesters being assaulted are afraid of reporting to the police because they might be prosecuted in turn. Many have avoided going to the hospital even injured because it is known that the police are arresting peaceful protesters when they seek treatment. Protest medics and underground doctors have stated that they were on the brink of collapse in handling cases.

Protesters have all the reasons to lose any kind of confidence in the police. And it is clear that the police is not protecting the people from any pro-government violence. There is no one coming to their rescue when help is needed. The people did not willfully take things into their own hands, but were forced by the circumstances. People resort to violence when facing assault because that is the only way they can protect themselves and their loved ones.

On the other hand, protesters also have a strong sense of justice. Time and again, they have seen thugs and mobsters let go by the police. The judicial system has lost people's trust when the lawbreakers are constantly released. This would be the very reason that excessive violence happens when the protesters get a chance to punish the thugs. It's not for the current act of the particular thug they face that they try to redress. It's for all the crimes of the lawbreakers that walk away under the police's watch.

I certainly agree that this kind of crude justice cannot replace the rule of law that we adhere to. But it is exactly why we should stand with the movement. The Hong Kong people has always been known as some of the most law-abiding citizens in the world. What turns us into violent protesters is the absence of the rule of law, the failure of the police and the judicial system.

The very answer to the current situation has already been written as the five demands, especially the last one. We want democracy now because that is our basic rights, which is promised in the joint declaration and our mini constitution, and that is the only way we can have a government accountable to the people. In so doing, we can start to rebuild our police force and judicial system. Only then, the Hong Kong people can be protected, and be sure that justice is upheld.

The Hong Kong and Chinese government might respond to the violence of people by an iron fist. Order might come by because of strong suppression. However, that would effectively make Hong Kong a police state. Without democracy and a government accountable to the people, oppression will persist. Police brutality will have no resolution. We already see how some corporations are required to fire employees that show their support for the movement on social media. We have good reasons to believe that this will become commonplace if the movement dies down.

It is a dire time for the Hong Kong people. Violence is escalating. Social order is crumbling down. But we are in the fight to rescue it and build it upon a real democracy. Please stand with us, stand with freedom.

Yours,
A Hongkonger

A Hongkonger

Dear friends,

Today we've seen Hong Kong protesters resorting to violence when a man attacked the protesters. Said man was critically injured. This would be unacceptable in many people's eyes. I am not trying to say that it should be encouraged but would like to provide a wider picture for the incidence and why we should still support the movement even with violence escalates.

Violence should be seen as the result of the collapse of the rule of law, which is wholly due to the failure of the police force and the judicial system. In the past 2 months, we have witnessed thugs and mobsters attacking protesters and civilians alike with no consequences. It is commonplace now that anyone who use violence against protesters can walk freely away, sometimes even escorted by the police. On the contrary, people beaten by pro-government camps were seen arrested. Many protesters being assaulted are afraid of reporting to the police because they might be prosecuted in turn. Many have avoided going to the hospital even injured because it is known that the police are arresting peaceful protesters when they seek treatment. Protest medics and underground doctors have stated that they were on the brink of collapse in handling cases.

Protesters have all the reasons to lose any kind of confidence in the police. And it is clear that the police is not protecting the people from any pro-government violence. There is no one coming to their rescue when help is needed. The people did not willfully take things into their own hands, but were forced by the circumstances. People resort to violence when facing assault because that is the only way they can protect themselves and their loved ones.

On the other hand, protesters also have a strong sense of justice. Time and again, they have seen thugs and mobsters let go by the police. The judicial system has lost people's trust when the lawbreakers are constantly released. This would be the very reason that excessive violence happens when the protesters get a chance to punish the thugs. It's not for the current act of the particular thug they face that they try to redress. It's for all the crimes of the lawbreakers that walk away under the police's watch.

I certainly agree that this kind of crude justice cannot replace the rule of law that we adhere to. But it is exactly why we should stand with the movement. The Hong Kong people has always been known as some of the most law-abiding citizens in the world. What turns us into violent protesters is the absence of the rule of law, the failure of the police and the judicial system.

The very answer to the current situation has already been written as the five demands, especially the last one. We want democracy now because that is our basic rights, which is promised in the joint declaration and our mini constitution, and that is the only way we can have a government accountable to the people. In so doing, we can start to rebuild our police force and judicial system. Only then, the Hong Kong people can be protected, and be sure that justice is upheld.

The Hong Kong and Chinese government might respond to the violence of people by an iron fist. Order might come by because of strong suppression. However, that would effectively make Hong Kong a police state. Without democracy and a government accountable to the people, oppression will persist. Police brutality will have no resolution. We already see how some corporations are required to fire employees that show their support for the movement on social media. We have good reasons to believe that this will become commonplace if the movement dies down.

It is a dire time for the Hong Kong people. Violence is escalating. Social order is crumbling down. But we are in the fight to rescue it and build it upon a real democracy. Please stand with us, stand with freedom.

Yours,
A Hongkonger

Hong Kong protests are growing smaller but more violent and ugly

By James Griffiths, CNN
Updated at 0416 GMT (1216 HKT) September 16, 2019



Hong Kong protests continue for 15th straight week 01:40

Hong Kong (CNN) — Dozens of people were injured Sunday in another night of violence in Hong Kong, as the city marked its fifteenth consecutive weekend of anti-government protests.

Thousands of people took part in a peaceful -- albeit unauthorized -- march from Causeway Bay to government offices in Admiralty, calling for the government to respond to the protest movement's five demands. That quickly turned violent after radical protesters gathered outside the legislature and began throwing bricks and petrol bombs at police lines.

Police responded with tear gas and water cannon, using jets of blue dye for the second time. The dye -- which is also laced with tear gas -- is designed to indelibly mark protesters and make them easy to arrest later.

The heavy response drove protesters back from the legislature and began a night of cat-and-mouse pursuit throughout the city, which saw protesters set fires and vandalize subway stations as police made sporadic arrests.

At least 28 people were injured Sunday, according to the hospital authority. Of those, 13 men and four women have been discharged as of Monday morning, while 11 remain in hospital. Two men are in a "serious condition," the authority said.



While the violence between police and protesters was fairly regular compared to previous weeks, the ugliest scenes occurred at the edges of the protests, where both protester and pro-government groups attacked people who disagreed with them.

CNN reporters saw a mob of masked protesters attacking a man in the Tin Hau neighborhood after a brief confrontation, leaving him dazed and bleeding on the floor. In an earlier incident, video shared widely online showed a middle-aged man wearing a blue shirt attacked and left apparently unconscious by a large group of mostly young, black-clad protesters on Gloucester Road. According to the South China Morning Post, the unidentified man had shouted pro-police slogans before the attack

Later on Sunday, a group of mostly middle-aged men were seen striking and threatening protesters in the North Point area. The area has a large mainland Chinese immigrant population, and there have been attacks on protesters in the area in past weeks.

Sunday's violence came after a number of angry scuffles on Saturday between pro and anti-government groups, though none reached the level of violence seen the following day. Pro-Beijing groups sang the Chinese national anthem and pulled down "Lennon Walls," collections of notes and flyers erected by protesters, around the city.

On Friday, pro-government lawmaker Junius Ho called on patriotic Hong Kongers to "get together and clean Hong Kong." Ho previously praised alleged triads who attacked protesters in Yuen Long, and appeared to threaten to kill one of his colleagues after they argued on a radio show.

https://edition-m.cnn.com/2019/09/15/asia/hong-kong-protest-violence-intl-hnk/index.html?r=android-app%3A%2F%2Fcom.google.android.googlequicksearchbox%2Fhttps%2Fwww.google.com
